Project Description  The Second Textbook Development Project will build on past Asian 
Development  Bank  (ADB)  assistance  to  continue  to  address  the 
availability  and  affordability  of  textbooks  in  basic  education.  The 
Project  will  extend  the  textbook  rental  scheme  (TRS)  established 
under the Basic Education Textbook Development Project (BETDP) to 
grades 6, 7, and 8. This will complete TRS coverage of all grades and 
all schools in the country. The Project will also establish appropriate 
institutional  arrangements  for  ensuring  sustainable  provision  of 
affordable textbooks.  
 
The Project will address other key issues in textbook and learning 
materials development, including reforming the national curriculum and 
encouraging  private  sector  growth  in  publishing  and  printing.  To 
support new approaches to learning, school libraries will be developed 
on a pilot basis as resource centers, with provision of books and other 
learning/teaching  materials,  adequate  furniture,  equipment,  and 
computers.  
   
Rationale  Given  the  dominant  role  of  textbooks  in  education  in  Uzbekistan, 
sustainable provision of affordable textbooks is key to improving the 
quality  and  relevance  of  basic  education.  The  Government  has 
recently strengthened the focus on basic education as the basis for 
development, and is giving the Project a high priority to support its 
National Program for School Education Development 2004–2009. 
   
Objective  The goal of the Project is to improve the quality of basic education. 
The  purpose  is  to  establish  efficient  and  sustainable  nationwide 
provision  of  affordable  textbooks,  and  other  instructional  materials, 
supported by necessary institutional and policy reforms.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to the Republic of Uzbekistan for the Second Textbook Development Project. 
 
 
II.  RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 
2.  According to Uzbekistan’s Constitution, every citizen is entitled to basic education, which 
is  provided  by  the  public  sector.  The  Government  requested  assistance  from  the  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) to address key constraints in basic education development, including 
the  sustainable  provision  of  affordable  textbooks  and  other  learning  materials,  curriculum 
reform, and school library development. The Project is designed to address these issues. The 
project framework is in Appendix 1.  
 
A.  Performance Indicators and Analysis 
3.  Basic education in Uzbekistan starts at age 6 and comprises grades 1 to 9. Senior 
secondary education continues from grades 10 to 12 and will be compulsory from 2010. Higher 
education consists of a 4-year bachelor of arts program followed by a 2-year masters program 
and then a doctoral program. Basic information on the education system and structure is in 
Appendix 2. 
 
4.  In 2003/04, of the 9,727 basic secondary schools, 2,006 (20.6%) were urban. This figure 
has been stable for the past 10 years. Of the 6.3 million students enrolled, 40.1% were in 
grades 1–4. The annual enrolment growth rate has averaged around 2.5% per year over the 
past 6 years, mainly reflecting continued recovery from the decline during the early transition 
years. In urban areas, net primary enrolment rates fell from 90.1% in 1990 to 87.8% in 1998; in 
rural areas the rates fell from 85.6% to 84.9%. The rates are currently estimated at 98%. 
However, the level of attendance is a problem especially in poor regions, although reliable data 
is not available. The cost and relevance of education may be among factors that affect school 
attendance. The primary completion rate is estimated to be high. The ratio of boys to girls in 
basic education is virtually 1:1, and 99.3% of the population is literate, with no significant gender 
differential in basic education.1 
 
5.  Education expenditure as a percentage of total budgets increased from 22.4% in 1997 to 
38% in 2003.2 Of particular note, public expenditure on clothing, textbooks, and other learning 
materials for grade 1 and poor and vulnerable students increased in real terms by around 150% 
between 1997 and 2002. The National Program for School Education Development (NPSED) 
2004–2009 was announced in June 2004 and envisages significant increases in investment in 
basic  education,  as  compared  with  the  emphasis  on  strengthening  senior  secondary  and 
vocational education over the past few years.

B.  Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 
6.  Notwithstanding the progress already made since the late 1990s, formidable challenges 
remain  for  the  Government  to  realize  its  long-term  goal  of  making  the  education  system 
consistent with a market-oriented economy and a democratic society in the 21st century. In 
basic education, the challenge is to improve quality and relevance, where textbooks play a key 
role  in  determining  student  performance.  ADB  approved  the  Basic  Education  Textbook 
Development Project (BETDP)3 in 1997 and has been initially successful in supporting textbook 
development and provision. A basic education subsector analysis with a problem tree is in 
Appendix 3.  
 
1.  Basic Education and Textbook Subsector Issues 
7.  Textbooks  and  Curriculum.  In  Uzbekistan  textbooks  are  almost  the  only  form  of 
teaching and learning support provided for both students and teaching staff. Therefore they are 
a key material input in influencing quality and relevance of basic education. In 1998, as a result 
of growing financial constraints, the Government terminated the policy of free provision of 
textbooks.  While  most  parents  found  textbooks  at  full  price  unaffordable,  suppliers  also 
struggled with uncertainty of demand and credit. By 2000, serious textbook shortages were 
being  experienced  in  many  schools.  In  2001,  the  BETDP  successfully  introduced  a  pilot 
textbook  rental  scheme  (TRS).  The  TRS  effectively  addressed  the  affordability  issue  by 
reducing parental expenditure on textbooks to an annual rental fee. The fee was approximately 
5 times cheaper than the total purchase price of a set of textbooks. Schools and parents 
strongly supported the TRS pilot, which achieved a collection rate of 93%. As a result of this 
success, the TRS was extended nationwide to cover grades 2–5 and 9.  
 
8.  National coverage of the TRS to include affordable core textbooks and teacher guides 
for all grades of basic education, except grade 1, is now needed.4 In addition, the institutional 
basis of the TRS needs to be placed on a sound footing so that the accumulated rental fees are 
professionally managed to ensure sustainability of textbook and teacher-guide provision. By 
2007,  centralized  funding  of  core  textbooks  and  teacher  guides  will  cease  and  textbook 
replacement supplies will be funded from the rental fee balances accumulated in school bank 
accounts. The transition from centralized to decentralized funding and from central to school-
based decision-making will require careful planning and management. National monitoring and 
supervision  of  the  TRS  within  the  Ministry  of  Public  Education  (MOPE)  also  needs  to  be 
improved and institutionalized. At present, the Government provides support for the socially 
unprotected—approximately 15% of the student population. This support is in the form of free 
textbooks and teacher guides provided to school libraries with schools in rich and poor areas 
receiving a similar proportion of free books. Targeting the poor must also be improved.  
 
9.  Curriculum and learning materials are closely connected. Curriculum design determines 
the  content,  sequencing,  methodology,  and  presentation  of  information  in  textbooks,  and 
therefore has a direct bearing on the nature and quality of the education provided. Although 
curriculum reform has been in progress since 1991, the Uzbek curriculum remains overloaded 
with too many subjects and an undue emphasis on rote learning rather than on developing key 
skills. The overloaded curriculum reinforces didactic, teacher-centered classroom approaches at 
the expense of student-centered learning (SCL) because teachers must rush through classes to

students. Such an overloaded curriculum also has high cost implications. Additional savings in 
textbook supply could be achieved by reducing curriculum textbook requirements. Successful

10.  A reformed assessment and testing system is central to upgrading the quality of basic 
education. Schools in Uzbekistan rely on tests that are made up and graded by individual 
teachers. With such a system, comparing student performance on a national, oblast, raion or 
school basis, or year-on-year basis is impossible. The reform of existing assessment practices 
must be synchronized with curriculum reform.  
 
11.  The Uzbek Constitution grants the right to citizens to education in their own languages, 
i.e., Russian, Karakalpak, Kazakh, Tajik, Kyrgyz, and Turkmen. To maintain cost and quality 
equity between the different language groups, the Government provides subsidies for minority 
language textbook publishing. However, the Government has had difficulty maintaining the 
necessary funding at the required level, especially in times of fiscal constraints. A review of 
language of instruction (LOI) practices is needed to ensure greater equity and to contribute to 
overall system cost reduction.  
 
12.  Information and communication technology (ICT) development in the school system is a 
stated priority of the Government. However, how best to integrate ICT in the curriculum to 
improve learning and teaching and the investment and recurrent cost implications of enhanced 
ICT provision are yet to be fully explored. Current ICT support is short term, with little prospect 
for sustainability. The need to develop a practical, affordable, and sustainable strategy for ICT 
provision in basic education is urgent. 
 
13.  Book Sector Development. Although textbook content is strongly influenced by the 
curriculum,  the  quality  and  cost  of  the  final  published  textbooks  depend  on  a  range  of 
specialized  publishing  and  production  skills,  which  include  the  editorial  and  financial 
conceptualization of textbooks and teacher guides, the identification of suitable authors, copy-
editing,  illustration,  design,  layout  and  presentation,  pre-press,  and  production.  The 
management of these specialist skills is essential for high-quality textbook publishing. While 
significant improvements in these areas have been achieved under the BETDP, much more 
work  is  needed  before  textbook  quality  in  Uzbekistan  reaches  international  standards. 
Unfortunately,  local  capacity  to  support  the  rapid  upgrading  of  professional  educational 
publishing and production remains underdeveloped. With the introduction of skill-based learning 
objectives and SCL methodologies, new textbooks and other learning materials will need to be 
professionally  conceived,  written,  presented,  and  produced.  Thus,  continued  professional 
support and capacity building is called for. 
 
14.  Other  sector  constraints  hindering  the  development  and  production  of  high-quality 
textbooks include (i) the lack of incentives to attract the best authors to participate in writing a 
new generation of textbooks, and (ii) the dominance of state-owned enterprises in textbook 
publishing and printing. To address the first constraint, effectiveness of implementation of the 
Copyright Law (1996) should be improved to enhance incentives and remuneration to authors. 
To address the second constraint, administrative and procedural streamlining is needed to 
facilitate participation by private publishers and printers. More broadly, however, the ongoing 
privatization process should be accelerated with appropriate restructuring, and other measures 
conducive to creating an equitable environment for private sector participation. These measures 
will lead to increased competition in the textbook sector, which will in turn improve textbook 
quality and lower prices.

15.  School  Library  Development  and  Supplementary  Materials.  The  dominance  of 
didactic, content-heavy textbooks as the main teaching/learning resource in Uzbek schools will 
create difficulties for developing more student-centered approaches to learning. The lack of 
relevant,  up-to-date  supplementary  materials,  reference  books,  and  curriculum  support 
materials in schools inhibits project work, individual student research, working alone or in small 
groups, and the development of wider reading around subjects. Any attempt to switch learning 
outcomes from factual recall to the development of appropriate skills will require that schools 
provide opportunities for students to take more responsibility for their own learning. The most 
basic and cost-effective resource required to support this fundamental switch in learning style is 
a well-stocked school library.  
 
16.  In Uzbekistan investment in school libraries has been minimal for many years, and few 
schools have the required resources and facilities to provide the more diverse learning support 
needed.5 The change to SCL cannot be achieved easily if the only available learning resources 
are the textbook and the teacher. The situation is exacerbated by teachers’ limited access to 
alternative sources of information. A good school library is as essential for teachers as it is for 
students. MOPE already recognizes the need for alternative learning materials to support and 
complement basic textbooks.  
 
17.  If learning styles are to be changed, low cost, user-friendly, well-stocked, open access 
school libraries need to be developed. Ideally, libraries should offer information to students in a 
variety of media. Internet access to wider information sources through library-based computers 
is an important component of school library systems elsewhere in the world. Before a cost-
effective ICT strategy for basic education is developed, low-cost compact disk technology could 
be used in the short to medium term. Meanwhile efforts should be devoted to developing 
suitable educational software in the Uzbek language.  
 
2.  The Project Rationale 
18.  The Project will build on the foundation established by the BETDP. As the first ADB 
assistance  to  Uzbekistan  in  the  education  sector,  the  BETDP  focused  on  improving  the 
availability, quality, and durability of textbooks and other instructional materials. In particular, the 
TRS piloted under the BETDP successfully addressed the urgent shortage of textbooks that 
was threatening the quality of, and access to, education after the Government abolished the 
policy of providing free textbooks in 1998. The TRS has proven to be an effective mechanism 
for providing affordable textbooks. A brief account of the experience of the TRS is in Appendix 
4.6  
 
19.  Progress made under the BETDP also includes (i) improving physical and presentational 
quality of textbooks; (ii) revising syllabi in six subjects; (iii) introducing of a new system of 
evaluation and approval of competing textbooks; (iv) strengthening teachers’ capacity through 
pilot in-service training; and (v) enhancing capacity through training in publishing and printing. 
By  improving  the  quality,  durability,  and  availability  of  textbooks  and  other  instructional 
materials, and enhancing the efficiency of the textbook production system, such progress has 
contributed significantly to improving the quality of basic education.

20.  The Project will consolidate and expand the considerable progress achieved under the 
BETDP in several key areas. These include the need for (i) affordable textbook provision to be 
extended to all grades in all schools; (ii) institutional strengthening of the TRS mechanism to 
ensure its long-term sustainability; (iii) a comprehensive curriculum review and reform, including 
reforms in examinations and assessment, and LOI practices and approaches to reduce the 
number of subjects and current content requirements (which will not only directly improve the 
quality and relevance of education, but also enhance sector efficiency and sustainability by 
bringing substantial cost savings in textbook provision); (iv) upgrading school libraries into 
learning resource centers to provide learning and teaching materials that are complementary to 
textbooks and the continued curriculum reform process, and an environment that promotes 
SCL; and (v) regulatory, institutional, and other support to strengthen the capacity of the private 
sector to participate in producing learning materials.  
 
21.  The Project is designed to address these issues in an integrated manner. Full provision 
of affordable textbooks is a precondition for improving quality and access to basic education, 
where improved targeting of existing government subsidies will ensure access of the poor to all 
required materials. Continued curriculum reform will lead to fundamental changes in classroom 
teaching and learning methodologies, supported by a new generation of textbooks and teacher 
guides. By reducing the number of subject and content requirements, the curriculum reform will 
reduce  parental  and  government  costs  for  textbooks  and  other  learning  materials.  Such 
efficiency gains will be enhanced by increased competition in the book sector through a greater 
role for the private sector. To support and complement these changes, adequately stocked 
school libraries as resource centers with increasing access to ICT are particularly important 
because  they  provide  students  and  teachers  with  additional  means,  materials,  and  the 
necessary environment.  
 
3.  Government Strategy and Policy  
22.  Since independence, the Government has given education a high priority in its reform 
agenda. This is reflected in the close attention senior government officials have paid to the 
sector and the consistently high budget allocations. The Government’s strategic objective is to 
transform the education system into one responsive to the requirements of a market economy 
and democratic society. To this end, the Government has undertaken many reform measures to 
address the challenges identified (paras. 7–17), especially since the unveiling of the National 
Program for Personnel Training in 1998. In basic education, significant achievements include (i) 
a marked improvement in efficiency and cost-effectiveness in textbook provision; (ii) continuing 
progress in curriculum reform that has led to a modest reduction in subjects for some grades; 
(iii) modernization and decentralization of the management system, including authorization for 
schools to raise and manage extrabudgetary resources, and establishment of school boards; 
(iv)  implementation  of  resource  rationalization  measures  with  regard  to  staff  and  other 
resources; and (v) provision of budget support to provide textbooks and clothing to children from 
low income families.  
 
23.  The NPSED 2004–2009 reaffirms the high priority of basic education and redirects focus 
and resources to improve basic education. The NPSED sets the priorities for the reform agenda 
over the next 5 years. They include (i) strengthening school infrastructure, especially rural 
schools, for basic education; (ii) increasing the supply of textbooks and other instructional 
materials,  as  well  as  computers  and  modern  laboratory  equipment;  (iii)  redesigning  and 
improving education content by revising the present state education standards, curriculum, and 
syllabi; (iv) strengthening teacher training and quality especially in rural areas by improving 
incentives and in-service training; and (v) encouraging private investment in basic education.

4.  Asian Development Bank Support for the Education Sector  
24.  A key objective of ADB’s country strategy for Uzbekistan is to reduce the social costs of 
transition. The education sector is a key focus. ADB’s sector strategy in education follows a two-
pronged approach of (i) supporting sector policy reforms and strengthening the national capacity 
to  manage  sector  reforms,  and  (ii)  supporting  specific  efforts  to  improve  the  quality  and 
relevance of education. In support of this approach, since 1998 ADB has provided five loans to 
the education sector, including the BETDP in 1998, the Senior Secondary Education Project7 in 
2000, and the Education Sector Development Program (ESDP)8 in 2002. In basic education, 
ADB’s policy dialogue and assistance have supported the Government in addressing key sector 
issues, including curriculum reform, improving the availability and affordability of textbooks and 
learning material production, strengthening teacher quality and development, promoting private 
sector participation, and enhancing planning and management capacities in basic education at 
all levels.  
 
25.  While  the BETDP  has  laid  the  foundation  for  the  Project,  the  ESDP  also  provides 
important  support,  given  its  objectives  to  (i)  strengthen  sector  planning  and  management 
capacities;  (ii)  improve  and  extend  teacher  education;  and  (iii)  reform  pro-poor  policy  and 
strengthen community involvement. The ESDP, once fully implemented, will support the Project 
by providing (i) a strong and coherent sector policy framework, (ii) stronger sector institutional 
capacity  for  the  successful  implementation  of  the  Project,  (iii)  enhanced  teacher  quality 
complementary to improved textbooks, and (iv) strengthened decision-making at schools.  
 
5.  External Support 
26.  As the lead provider of financial assistance in the sector, ADB has maintained close 
coordination with other funding agencies to ensure complementary and consistent approaches 
(Appendix 5). The United States Agency for International Development has two pilot projects 
(totaling $5 million) for improving teacher quality, teaching, equipment including computers, and 
community involvement; and strengthening school management. The United Nations Children’s 
Fund (UNICEF) is also piloting similar support to several schools. These projects, while limited 
in scope and geographic coverage, complement ADB’s assistance in testing out innovative 
approaches  and  methods  to  improve  quality  and  relevance  of  basic  education.  Recently, 
funding agencies have enhanced coordination for basic education reforms.  
 
6.  Lessons Learned  
27.  Weak  Institutional  and  Implementation  Capacity.  The  absorptive  capacity  of 
executing agencies remains weak due to their limited experience with ADB procedures, and 
difficulty  recruiting  and  retaining  project  and  other  professional  staff.  Personnel  with  the 
necessary skills mix are scarce, and salaries are low. Excessively bureaucratic decision-making 
processes, lack of delegation of authority to project implementers, and deficient interagency 
coordination are other features that can cause delays in key project implementation activities 
such as consultant recruitment, procurement of goods, and disbursements. The Project will 
address these by (i) retaining the project management and implementation structure, including 
the core group of the BETDP’s project implementation unit (PIU); and (ii) significantly building

28.  Experience from Other Textbook Projects. A common lesson learned in textbook

III.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT 
A.  Objective 
30.  The goal of the Project is to improve the quality of basic education. The purpose is to 
establish  efficient  and  sustainable  nationwide  provision  of  affordable  textbooks,  and  other 
instructional materials, supported by necessary institutional and policy reforms.  
  
B.  Components and Outputs 
31.  The Project comprises four components: (i) strengthening the basic education policy 
framework,  (ii)  ensuring  the  sustainable  provision  of  textbooks,  (iii)  developing  the  book 
publishing sector, and (iv) developing school libraries.  
 
1.  Strengthening the Basic Education Policy Framework 
32.  This component will strengthen the national curriculum for basic education. Curriculum 
reform as an ongoing process has an essential impact on sector efficiency and the sustainability 
of basic education, and provides the basis for long-term enhancement of quality and relevance 
of  basic  education.  This  component  will  also  strengthen  the  national  assessment  and 
examination  system,  which  is  necessary  to  ensure  quality  in  implementing  educational 
standards and contents required by a modernized curriculum. A number of research studies will 
be undertaken, focusing on key educational policy issues, including a national ICT development 
strategy in education, and LOI practices.

subgroups. International consultants with expertise and experience in these areas will provide 
assistance as required. A limited amount of office equipment and administrative support will also 
be provided to the working group.  
 
2.  Ensuring the Sustainable Provision of Textbooks 
36.  This component will extend the TRS to grades 6, 7, and 8 to complete the coverage of 
the TRS for all core subjects at all grade levels (except grade 1) in all schools. It will also 
develop and institutionalize the legal mechanism necessary to ensure financial sustainability 
and proper management of the TRS. 
 
37.  Outputs from this component will be (i) textbook supplies on all core subjects for grades 
6, 7, and 8 in all schools; (ii) free textbook provision for the poorest students through better 
targeting  mechanisms;  (iii)  legal  establishment  and  operation  of  the  republican  textbook 
revolving  fund  foundation  (RTRFF),  as  a  mechanism  to  ensure  long-term  and  sustainable 
textbook provision; and (iv) decentralized, school-based decision-making on textbook selection 
and related financial and managerial matters.  
 
38.  Key activities will include the following:  
 
(i)  Ensure competitive selection, procurement, and distribution of core textbooks for 
grades 6, 7, and 8, to complete the full grade level and core subject coverage of 
the TRS established under the BETDP. Procurement will include 13.7 million 
textbooks (20 titles) for grades 6 and 7 in 2005, accompanied by 0.6 million 
teacher guides, and 9.6 million textbooks (14 titles) for grade 8 in 2006 and 0.4 
million teacher guides. 
 
(iii)  Ensure annual provision from the Government budget of textbook rental fee 
support to around 15% of enrolled students in the basic education system who 
are categorized as socially unprotected and cannot afford even the reduced

9 
rental fees. Undertake a study to clearly establish scope, locations, and effective 
mechanisms for better targeting support for the poor.  
 
(iii)   Establish  the  RTRFF  to  assume  responsibility  for  the  proper  and  prudent 
management and timely disbursement of the accumulated rental fees on behalf 
of schools and parents. A board of trustees, including representatives of MOPE, 
the Ministry of Finance, schools, and parents will supervise the RTRFF. The 
RTRFF will not take its own decisions on the use of accumulated school rental 
funds, but will ensure that the decisions taken by schools to order new and 
replacement textbooks are efficiently and properly executed. The establishment 
of RTRFF is described in Appendix 6. 
 
(iv)   Design and establish a nationwide system to support school-based ordering of 
new and replacement textbooks when competing alternative textbooks come on 
stream during the course of the Project. The system will maintain the cost-
reducing benefits of centralized bulk purchase, and support decentralized school-
based decision-making. 
 
(v)   Review and amend, as required, the existing procedures and documentation for 
the competitive submission, evaluation, and approval of textbooks and other 
learning materials. This will ensure the procurement of high quality books and 
materials that are well-suited to the specified needs and requirements of the 
modernized curriculum learning objectives and the shift to school-based ordering 
under  the  RTRFF;  and  may  entail  revision  of  minimum  physical  production 
specifications (set under the BETDP) to achieve durable textbooks within the 
capacity of local and regional production facilities. 
 
(vi)   Monitor and supervise the TRS to maintain collection rates at the level required 
to ensure its long-term financial sustainability.  
 
3.  Developing the Book Publishing Sector 
39.   This component will continue the process, begun under the BETDP, of upgrading skills 
in the chain of textbook and learning material development including authorship, publishing, 
production, and distribution. Specifically, it will provide financial and technical support for the 
development of short-term, in-service book sector skills training at a selected local educational 
institution; the goal is to establish permanent local training capacity in the full range of skills 
required  for  book  publishing  and  the  development  of  other  educational  materials.  The 
component will also seek to create conditions for a more active private sector role in the book 
sector, including the improvement of incentives and remuneration for quality authorship, and 
equal access to the textbook market by private sector publishers and printers.  
 
40.  Outputs  of  this  component  will  be  (i)  a  sustainable  institutional  base  for  continued 
upgrading of professional, commercial, and management skills in book sector development; (ii) 
strengthened capacity in authorship and publishing through workshops and training; and (iii) 
increased  representation  of  private  publishers  on  the  MOPE-approved  book  lists  and 
procurement contracts for textbooks and other materials under the Project. 
 
41.  Key activities will include (i) establishing a permanent base for capacity building at a 
local public educational institution selected by the Government; (ii) developing and conducting 
short training courses on the full range of educational book development skills; (iii) reviewing

10 
publishing licensing procedures for textbooks and related regulatory barriers to the publishing 
industry, and making recommendations for their improvement; (iv) reviewing current regulations, 
practices, and incentives for educational authors and publishers; and making recommendations 
for their improvement; and (v) supporting implementation of recommendations approved by the 
Government. Policy review and recommendations, and other related advisory work and capacity 
building will be mainly conducted by locally selected consultants with expertise in these areas 
under the guidance and assistance of international experts. Limited equipment will be provided 
to the host institution selected for capacity building. 
 
4.  Developing School Libraries 
42.  This component will strengthen and develop school libraries as resource centers for 
learning and teaching. Well-equipped and well-stocked school libraries providing study spaces 
for  approximately  10%  of  school  enrolment  will  be  important  for  upgrading  the  quality  of 
education in Uzbekistan. They will provide (i) alternative sources of information, which to date 
has been dominated by textbooks; (ii) necessary facilities and environment for the development 
of  student  research,  project  work,  and  independent  learning;  and  (iii)  key  methodological 
support  for  introducing  and  nurturing  a  more  interactive  SCL  approach.  In  addition,  well-
developed school libraries contribute significantly to long-term system cost reduction. Given the 
importance of modernized school libraries, the NPSED 2004–2009 has made improvement of 
the school library system nationwide a priority. 
 
43.  Outputs from this component will be (i) national guidelines for school library system 
improvement; (ii) 1,000 refurbished, upgraded, and well-stocked school libraries (10% of the 
total);  and  (iii)  improvement  of  skills  through  training  of  1,000  school  librarians  and  200 
oblast/raion specialists. In addition, management and monitoring of textbook use under the TRS 
will be strengthened in each library. Selected school libraries must (i) include at least 40% from 
poor  and  rural  raions,  with  some  from  minority  language  schools;  and  (ii)  have  strong 
commitment and support from their local governments and communities. (An outline of selection 
criteria for working groups and school library development is in Appendix 7).  
 
44.  Key activities under this component will include (i) developing national guidelines for 
school  library  systems,  training  materials,  and  monitoring  and  evaluation  schemes;  (ii) 
conducting a base-line study of teaching/learning styles and performance in a number of skills 
and aptitudes prior to or shortly after the introduction of modernized school libraries, with follow-
up studies to be administered every 2 years to measure improvement in learning/teaching styles 
and performance levels over time; (iii) refurbishing, furnishing, and upgrading 1,000 pilot school 
libraries in accordance with national standards; (iv) providing basic audiovisual equipment to the 
upgraded  school  libraries;  (v)  publishing,  via  competitive  selection,  about  700  specially 
developed school library titles that are well spread among grade levels and subject areas and 
designed  to  support  student  reading  and  research  in  accordance  with  modernized  state 
education standards, curriculum, and syllabi; (vi) developing software in Uzbek language via 
grants awarded on a bidding basis; (vii) training a cadre of library professionals and teachers, 
who will undertake raion-based training of library methodologists and school librarians; and (viii) 
monitoring, supervising and evaluating the school library development. Local experts assisted 
by international consultants will be employed to review and prepare relevant national policies, 
and  to  provide  capacity  building  and  monitor  implementation  in  these  areas.  Furniture, 
equipment including ICT equipment, and stocks of library materials will be provided to pilot 
school  libraries.  The  Government  will  fund  and  undertake  minor  rehabilitation  of  selected 
libraries, where necessary.

C.  Special Features 
45.  Pro-Poor Design. The Project will improve affordability and availability of textbooks to 
the poor. Under the TRS, about 15% of students cannot afford the rental fees. While the Project 
will extend the scheme to cover all grades (2–9) in all schools, it will also develop measures and 
mechanisms to improve the Government’s subsidy program by improving targeting of the poor. 
This is envisaged to be implemented through a combination of geographic targeting and more 
effective delivery mechanisms with participation of teacher-parent councils and the Mahalla 
(local community) system. The Project will also ensure that of the 1,000 schools to be selected 
for library improvement, at least 40% are in poor regions. (A recommendation to MOPE on 
improvement of school libraries is in Supplementary Appendix A.)  
 
46.  Institutional Change and Decentralization. The Project will institutionalize the TRS by 
establishing the RTRFF. As the apex organization, the RTRFF will take charge of the financial 
and  management  responsibilities  required  to  ensure  sustainable  and  affordable  nationwide 
textbook provision under the supervision of a board including representatives of Government, 
schools, and parents. Nationwide, schools and parents will be accountable for making decisions 
concerning textbooks (particularly after competing alternative textbooks come on stream) and 
other related educational and financial matters. By supporting a shift from the current mainly 
centralized  and  supply-determined  system  to  decentralized  and  demand-driven  decision-
making, the RTRFF will further the empowerment process begun under the BETDP.  
 
47.  Community Involvement and Participatory Approach. The Project’s design followed 
a participatory approach, with the full participation of all stakeholders including oblast and raion 
education departments, Hakimyats (local executive branch of the government), school directors, 
teachers, parents, and Mahalla representatives, as well as ministries of central Government 
(Supplementary Appendix B). This took various forms including participatory rural appraisal 
techniques  to  consult  with  the  poor,  regular  planning  workshops,  presentations,  and 
consultation. The Project will continue the emphasis on full participation during implementation, 
including a national publicity campaign on extending the TRS and strengthening community and 
parent involvement in management of the TRS and the RTRFF.

62.  In addition to regular twice-annual reviews of the Project, comprehensive reviews of 
project performance will be conducted at the end of the first and third years of implementation, 
given that much of the policy research and advisory work will be carried out during the first 
years of implementation. The first comprehensive review will focus on the success of policy 
advisory work and implementation arrangements. The second (midterm) review will (i) review 
the scope, design, and implementation arrangements of the Project; (ii) identify any changes 
required since the time of project appraisal; (iii) assess progress of project implementation 
against  performance  indicators;  (iv)  establish  compliance  with  loan  covenants;  and  (v)  if 
necessary, recommend changes in the design or implementation arrangements. The paper and 
equipment revolving funds established under the National Bank of Uzbekistan11 are an integral 
part of the Government and ADB’s approach to developing the textbook sector. Given that the 
effective functioning of the revolving funds is essential to the successful development of the 
textbook sector being supported by the Project, it will be a subject of review in all project 
reviews. 
 
9.  Anticorruption Measures 
63.  The  Mission  explained  ADB’s  anticorruption  policy  to  Government  officials  and 
highlighted paragraphs 1.06 to 1.08 of ADB’s Guidelines for Procurement on issues concerning 
fraud  and  corruption.  The  Government  agreed  to  include  the  relevant  sections  of  ADB’s 
anticorruption policy in all documents and contracts during bidding for and implementation of the 
Project. 
 
IV.  PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, AND RISKS 
A.  Project Benefits and Beneficiaries 
64.  Direct Beneficiaries. The Project will benefit 6 million students annually in grades 2–9 
by reducing parental contributions to the cost of textbooks. Of these students, 27.5% are from

16 
poor families and 6.6% are from ethnic minority groups.12 The provision of supplementary 
reading materials and school libraries will be targeted to ensure that 40% of beneficiaries will be 
schools from poor regions. Secondary beneficiaries will include 160,000 teachers and about 
1,200 school librarians and specialists who will receive new teacher guides and formal in-
service training in the use of new textbooks and the new school library facilities. In addition, 40 
curriculum developers and assessment specialists, 270 textbook evaluators, a new generation 
of textbook authors and publishers, and the printing industry will benefit from training in modern 
techniques in their respective professional areas. The provision of basic ICT capacity in 1,000 
school libraries will help to develop new and sustainable policies for any future ICT investments 
in the sector. 
 
65.  Educational Benefits. The key role of textbooks as one of the most important factors 
determining student performance is well established. The most important educational benefit of 
the Project will derive from the completion and establishment of the TRS and the establishment 
of the RTRFF, which will ensure the sustainable provision of core textbooks for every grade 
level  to  every  student  in  the  country  at  affordable  prices.  The  provision  of  targeted  TRS 
subsidies by the Government will ensure that the full range of textbooks will also be available to 
poor students.  
 
66.  The design of an improved and more relevant curriculum will introduce new skill and 
competency-based  learning  objectives,  oriented  more  precisely  to  the  needs  of  a  market-
oriented,  democratic  society.  The  new  curriculum  will  encourage  students  to  take  more 
responsibility for their own learning, and will aim to develop higher order thinking and problem-
solving skills and the ability to apply acquired knowledge. A reduced content burden will allow 
for more classroom time to be devoted to understanding rather than rote learning and for more 
productive  interaction  between  teaching  staff  and  students.  The  development  of  new  and 
improved textbooks, combined with the introduction of upgraded school libraries will support the 
introduction of SCL and teaching methodologies. The upgraded school libraries will contain a 
wider collection of reading, supplementary, reference, and curriculum support materials in a 
variety of media. The provision of library-based computers with Internet access will also widen 
the scope of information available to students and teachers. Thus, the library development 
component  will  provide  genuine  opportunities  for  individual  and  small  groups  working  and 
conducting research, which in turn will encourage wider reading and thinking around curriculum 
subjects and the ability of students to explore and develop their own interests. 
 
67.  Reform of the assessment system will ensure that the new learning objectives can be 
adequately tested and is expected to lead to more open, fair, and transparent summative 
assessments. The development of formative tests will enable the more accurate measurement 
of  system  progress  toward  defined  educational  goals.  An  assessment  of  the  current  LOI 
practices  will  provide  the  basis  for  supporting  improved  educational  quality  and  equity  in 
minority language schools. The Project will also support the training of a cadre of curriculum, 
assessment, and LOI specialists; and will train over 1,200 librarians and specialists in the use of 
upgraded school libraries and a wide range of supplementary materials. Maintenance and 
teacher support facilities in the effective use of ICT will be developed in all raions. 
 
68.  Financial and Economic Analysis. Under normal assumptions, including that on the 
collection  rate  and  based  on  experience  of  the  piloting  and  subsequent  partial  national 
extension under the BETDP during 2000–2003, the TRS will be financially sustainable, i.e., the 
accumulated textbook rental fees over the 4 years of the replacement cycle will be sufficient to

cover the cost of replacing the textbooks. With regard to fiscal impact, the total Government 
commitment to externally funded projects in education, including $30 million to the Project and 
other commitments (mainly to the ESDP and  the Senior Secondary Education Project), is 
compared  with  the  annual  education  budget  for  the  years  2005–2009,  with  two  scenarios 
depending on projections of budget revenue. In both cases, Government commitments are 
deemed  affordable  and  sustainable:  in  the  high-case  scenario  the  Government’s  annual 
commitment as a percentage of the education budget ranges from 5.4% to 2.8%, averaging 
3.6% over the 5-year life of the Project; while in the low case scenario, it ranges from 5.2% to 
3.9%, averaging 4.3% over the 5-year life of the Project. The annual recurrent costs of the three 
projects combined are only 0.1% of the annual education recurrent budget for both high and low 
case scenarios.  
 
69.  While total economic costs of the Project consist of textbook rental fees paid by the 
parents  and  the  total  project  cost,  the  Project  will  bring  substantial  economic  benefits. 
Quantifiable economic benefits derive from several sources. First, curriculum reform is expected 
to reduce the number of textbooks thereby reducing the price of the textbook set for each grade. 
Second, the provision of textbooks under the TRS to grades 6, 7, and 8 will bring significant 
benefits to students and parents as the rental fees are four times cheaper than full textbook 
purchase prices. Third, increasing competition in the book sector is expected to bring efficiency 
gains  that  will  be  reflected  largely  in  lower  prices  of  textbooks,  further  reducing  parents’ 
contributions to rental fees. The sum of these quantifiable economic benefits under reasonable 
assumptions will far outweigh the total economic costs. The economic internal rate of return of 
the Project is calculated to be 30%. The resulting net economic benefits will be enhanced by 
significant nonquantifiable economic benefits that the Project will impart (a fuller analysis is in 
Supplementary Appendix E). 
 
70.  Poverty Impact. Recent data indicate that 27.5% of the population or 6.8 million people, 
live at or below the poverty line and nearly 70% of all poor reside in rural areas.13 The Project 
will contribute to poverty reduction by improving the quality of, and access to, basic education 
for students in grades 2–9. The Project will address the issue of access to basic education for 
the poorest pupils by  developing an effective mechanism for providing targeted rental fee 
subsidies in the form of free textbooks for the poorest pupils nationwide. Forty percent of the 
1,000 upgraded school libraries will be selected from schools in poor regions, which will lead to 
higher educational achievement of pupils in poor schools. Curriculum reform is expected to lead 
to  further  cost  reduction  via  reduced  rental  fee  charges  for  textbooks  and  other  learning 
materials, which is one of the major barriers to participation by poor students (Appendix 15). 
 
71.  Social Dimension. The Project will contribute to the accumulation of human capital, 
which is essential for higher incomes, and reduces poverty and vulnerability of the poor. The 
Project  will  increase  community  participation  in  financial  and  managerial  accountability, 
including in the allocation of rental fee financial support to the poorest. The Project will ensure 
that ethnic minority students speaking Russian and Karakalpak will benefit from continued 
access to instructional materials. The current situation with regard to LOI practices will be 
assessed  and  recommendations  will  be  provided  to  minimize  costs  and  improve  future 
employment opportunities for ethnic minorities. The Project will continue to mainstream gender 
equity based on progress made under the BETDP through universal textbook provision, and by 
correcting gender stereotyping and bias in textbook development.

72.  Environmental and Social Safeguards. The Project will involve minor library repair and 
internal refurbishing, with no negative environmental or resettlement impact. The Project will

B.  Risks 
73.  The  Project  faces  sector,  financial,  institutional,  and  coordination  risks  that  are 
outweighed by the benefits and impacts. 
 
74.  Sector Risk. The Project is designed in the context of and supports the education sector 
reforms being implemented by the Government. A reversal or slowdown of the sector reforms 
could have an adverse impact on the Project. To mitigate such systemic risk, ADB will continue 
to assist with sector reform and management. As the major provider of financial assistance in 
the education sector, ADB has pursued a consistent strategy of policy dialogue supported with 
assistance in key areas. This strategy has yielded demonstrable results. The recently unveiled 
NPSED 2004–2009 is also a clear indication of the Government’s commitment to continuing 
reform and strengthening basic education.  
 
75.  Financial Risk. The financial sustainability of the TRS, a key component of the Project, 
will depend on (i) maintaining a collection rate sufficient for replacing textbooks at regular 
intervals,  and  (ii)  managing  the  accumulated  rental  fees.  The  RTRFF  will  be  established 
specifically  to  address  this  risk  by  ensuring  professional  management  of  the  rental  fees 
accumulated under the TRS, and systematic supervision and monitoring at central, oblast, 
raion, and school levels. Experience with national extension in the past 2 years in Uzbekistan, 
and  in  other  countries,  highlights  the  crucial  importance  of  the  RTRFF  in  maintaining  the 
financial sustainability of textbook provision. Experience of the BETDP’s PIU, which will be 
applied to implementing the Project, will contribute significantly to mitigating this risk.  
 
76.  Institutional  and  Coordination  Risk.  Successful  project  implementation  requires 
significant institutional capacity for the Government to ensure effective coordination among 
central  agencies  and  at  all  levels  of  government.  Such  coordination  will  be  essential  to 
extending the TRS, as calendar deadlines of school years must be met to provide textbooks on 
time. Similarly, syllabus revision resulting from curriculum reform must be synchronized with the 
textbook replacement cycles to avoid unnecessary redundancies. With regard to school library 
improvement, physical repair of libraries, refurbishing, equipment provision, and library book 
provision  must  be  well  sequenced  and  carried  out  by  different  agencies.  In  addition, 
coordination is needed between the Project and teacher training component of the ESDP. This 
institutional and coordination risk will be mitigated by (i) building on the experience at all levels 
of government including the PIU, gained from implementation of the BETDP; (ii) improving 
coordination and monitoring ability resulting from ADB past assistance including the Education 
Reform  Implementation  and  Monitoring  Unit  at  COM;  (iii)  enhancing  efficiency  result  from 
Government implementation of the NPSED 2004–2009; and (iv) continuing MOPE efforts to 
build mechanisms for better coordination between the Project and the ESDP. 
 
V.  ASSURANCES  
A.  Government Assurances  
77.  In  addition  to  the  standard  assurances,  the  Government  has  given  the  following 
assurances, which are incorporated in the legal documents.

19 
78.  Government Counterpart Funding. The Government will allocate in a timely manner 
adequate funding in the budget for (i) the Government’s share of procurement of textbooks for 
the school years of 2005/06 and 2006/07 under the Project; (ii) support under the TRS for 
textbooks for those socially unprotected who cannot afford the textbook rental fees; (iii) the 
rehabilitation and provision of furniture for the 1,000 pilot school libraries according to the 
Project’s  implementation  schedule;  and  (iv)  incremental  recurrent  costs  for  operation  and 
maintenance of the refurbished and modernized pilot school libraries. 
 
79.  Curriculum Reform and Textbook Development. The Government will ensure that (i) 
the  curriculum  framework  working  group  is  established  by  1  February  2005;  and  (ii)  the 
introduction  of  new  syllabi  will  synchronize  with  textbook  replacement  cycles  to  avoid 
unnecessary redundancy, with new syllabi for grades 4 and 5 completed by September 2006 
and introduced by September 2007, and other revised grade level syllabi following annually.  
 
80.  Establishment  of  Republican  Textbook  Revolving  Fund  Foundation.  The 
Government will (i) issue a formal decision on the establishment of the RTRFF by 15 December 
2004, as an independent legal entity in the form of a noncommercial republican foundation, to 
manage the rental fees accumulated under the TRS, and textbook procurement and distribution 
pursuant to orders placed by schools, operating on principles of transparency, accountability, 
participation by schools and parents, and financial prudence, as agreed upon with ADB; (ii) by 
30 January 2005 register the RTRFF charter with consultation and agreement of ADB prior to its 
registration; and (iii) ensure that the RTRFF will be fully operational by 1 February 2005.  
 
81.  The RTRFF will be governed by a board of trustees, whose composition should include 
representatives of parent councils, the Mahalla system, school administrations, oblast/raion 
public education departments, MOPE, Ministry of Finance, Ministry of Economy, Ministry of 
Justice, and the Central Bank of Uzbekistan. ADB will be an observer on the board of trustees. 
The board of trustees will appoint RTRFF management. 
 
82.  School Library Development. The Government will approve the selection of 1,000 pilot 
school libraries under the Project by the end of 2005 according to the criteria agreed upon with 
ADB—125 will be identified by the completion of physical improvements before the start of 
school year 2005/06.  
 
83.  The Government will ensure that physical improvement of pilot school libraries will (i) 
take place prior to procurement of equipment for libraries; (ii) be closely coordinated with 
implementation of other relevant project components, and follow designs agreed to by ADB to 
meet  requirements  of  subsequent  improvements;  and  (iii)  have  no  negative  environmental 
impact or land acquisition or resettlement implications. 
 
84.  Book  Sector  Development.  The  Government  will  ensure  that  provisions  of  the 
Copyright Law (1996) will be effectively implemented and in particular author remunerations are 
determined between publishers and authors according to relevant provisions of the law. 
 
85.  The Government will ensure that any interested publisher and printer satisfying criteria 
laid out by the bidding documents under the Project will be allowed to participate in the bidding. 
 
86.  The Government will continue to take timely and effective measures to improve the 
policy and regulatory framework of the book sector in order to enhance competition and private 
sector growth. Progress in this regard will be a subject of specific review by ADB and the 
Government within 1 year after the loan becomes effective.

20 
87.  National  Guidelines  for  School  Libraries.  By  the  end  of  2005,  MOPE  will  adopt  
national guidelines for the school library system developed by the Project.  
 
88.  Pro-Poor Targeted Subsidy. The Government will adopt measures by the end of 2005 
for improving targeted subsidy to the poorest under the TRS including more effective delivery 
mechanisms with the participation of teachers, parents, and Mahalla system, based on the 
recommendations of a study that will be completed under the Project by September 2005.  
 
89.  Coordination  between  the  Education  Sector  Development  Program  and  the 
Project. The Government will appoint the same director for the Project and the ESDP to 
strengthen effective coordination during implementation of the two projects.  
 
B.  Conditions for Disbursement 
90.  The  Government’s  full  compliance  with  the  assurance  on  the  establishment  of  the 
RTRFF as specified in paras. 80–81 will be a condition for disbursement for procurement of 
textbooks and other instructional materials.

BASIC EDUCATION SUBSECTOR ANALYSIS 
 
 
1.  The Government’s stated long-term reform goal for education is to transform the system 
into one that is consistent with a market-oriented economy and a democratic society in the 21st 
century. To realize this aspiration, basic education as a subsector faces the key challenge to 
improve quality and relevance, as analyzed in the following (a problem tree is attached).  
 
2.  Governance and Institutional Constraints. As a priority in the overall government 
reform agenda, basic education has received significant fiscal and other support over the past 
decade and managed to avoid the dramatic decline in enrolment witnessed in some transition 
countries. However, within an overall highly centralized bureaucratic system, basic education, 
like other subsectors, is still largely governed by rigid norms set by the central Government. For 
example, most items in the annual school budgets are fixed and schools have discretionary 
spending authority over only a small portion of the budget. In all subjects taught, programs and 
standards set by the central Government strictly dictate the contents and time allocated for the 
subjects,  leaving  inadequate  freedom  for  schools  to  adjust  to  student  needs  and  local 
conditions. State norms fix student-teacher ratios countrywide, and schools have neither power 
nor budgetary incentives to strive for optimal use of existing resources. As a result, the system 
does not encourage nor support capacity building in planning and management skills. While the 
Mahalla  (local  community)  system  has  played  an  important  role  as  part  of  the  overall 
government social protection system, community participation and involvement in key decision-
making remains limited.  
 
3.  To address equity concerns and protect the poor, the Government has allocated fiscal 
support for the free provision of textbooks and clothing for the poorest 15% of the school 
population. At present, this support is inadequately targeted because of the practical difficulties 
in providing compensatory budget support for areas with higher than average levels of poverty. 
The problem is also due to the unavailability of poverty indicators for raions and school, which 
are necessary to achieve better targeting.  
 
4.  Currently, the private sector does not participate in the provision of basic education. 
State-owned  enterprises  dominate  publishing  and  printing  of  textbooks  and  educational 
materials. The nascent and weak private sector and the emergence of a competitive educational 
book market could benefit a great deal from continuing privatization, but first, the Government 
must accelerate efforts to create an equitable environment and improved access for private 
sector involvement in the textbook market. Growing competition in this subsector would lead to 
increased external efficiency through higher quality and lower prices of textbooks and other 
educational materials.  
 
5.  Curriculum and Other Educational Policies. Curriculum reform has been ongoing 
since 1991 and progress has been made in reforming state education standards and in reducing 
the number of subjects and the amount of specified content for the school year 2003/04. 
Overall, the curriculum remains overloaded with an undue emphasis on factual memorization 
and on repetitive exercises rather than on the development of key skills and competencies. An 
overloaded  curriculum  reinforces  didactic  teacher-centered  classroom  approaches  at  the 
expense  of  student-centered  learning  methodologies  because  teachers  must  rush  through 
classes to meet to meet the heavy content requirements, leaving no time for interaction with and 
among students. Such a curriculum also has high cost implications as each subject requires a 
textbook and each book has far too much extent. As the cornerstone of an education system

suitable for the new millennium, comprehensive curriculum reform is needed as the centerpiece 
of the reform agenda for basic education. 
 
6.  A modernized assessment and testing system is integral to the system to ensure the 
quality of basic education. At present, tests in schools are graded by individual teachers in the 
lower grades and noneffective national tests prior to graduation. Under such a system, no 
effective and reliable way is available to assess and compare the quality of basic education 
provided  on  a  national,  oblast,  raion,  or  school  basis,  and  no  way  to  compare  student 
performance year-on-year or internationally. Existing assessment and testing practices need to 
be modernized, together with curriculum reform to ensure an effective, fair, and transparent 
system that will support improvements in the quality and relevance of basic education.  
 
7.  The current language of instruction (LOI) policy guarantees the rights of ethnic minorities 
to education in Russian, Karakalpak, Kazakh, Tajik, Kyrgyz, and Turkmen, in addition to Uzbek. 
The  Government  has  struggled  to  maintain  this  policy  by  providing  subsidies  for  minority 
language textbook publishing especially in times of fiscal strains. Reform of LOI policies will help 
ensure greater equity in the provision of education to the different national language groups and 
will also contribute to overall system cost reduction. 
 
8.  Information and Communication Technology (ICT) development in the school system is 
also a stated priority of the Government as a central requirement for human development and 
education provision in the 21st century. However, how ICT development can and should be 
integrated in the curriculum to improve learning and teaching is unclear. In addition, huge 
investment and recurrent cost implications of this policy requirement are yet to be fully explored 
and understood. Present ICT support is mostly driven by funding agencies and short-term 
based, with little or no concern for longer-term financial sustainability. A practical, affordable and 
sustainable strategy for ICT development in schools is urgently needed. 
 
9.  Learning and Teaching Materials. Textbooks are the dominant means of learning and 
teaching and thus the key material input in influencing quality and relevance of basic education. 
In former Soviet times and prior to 1998, the Government provided textbooks. Due to increasing 
fiscal and financial strains, the Government decided to cease the free provision of textbooks and 
adopted the policy of user charges. Immediately afterwards, textbooks were in short supply 
because the majority of parents could not afford to buy them. The textbook rental scheme (TRS) 
successfully  introduced  in  2000  effectively  addressed  the  affordability  issue  by  reducing 
parental expenditure on textbooks to a rental fee. The fee was approximately 5 times cheaper 
than the total purchase price of a set of textbooks from the market. The TRS was subsequently 
extended nationwide to cover grades 2–5 and 9, with national coverage of grade 2–9 to be 
completed by the end of 2007. Further cost savings in basic textbook provision could be 
achieved by reducing textbook requirements; this could be achieved by revising curriculum 
specifications and making other policy improvements. Currently, textbooks are still in need of 
improved professional skills in writing, illustration, page design, layout, and presentation to 
make them more user friendly and thus enhance student interest and learning impact.  
 
10.  While textbooks will remain for many years the fundamental learning and teaching tool, 
modern, open access school libraries can play a key role as resource centers in supporting a 
modern curriculum and student-centered learning. As such, they provide a wider range of 
alternative  materials,  viewpoints,  and  approaches  that  supplement  and  extend  the  basic 
textbooks. They also create an environment in which students can take greater responsibility for 
their own learning through individual and small group research, discovery, and project work on 
themes from the subjects that they study in class. This support is integral to competency-based

learning objectives and the development of higher order thinking skills. Unfortunately, school 
libraries in Uzbekistan do not meet these requirements. They need to improve management, 
provide adequate space, up-to-date and relevant stock, and the most basic equipment to aid 
learning  and  teaching.  A  reformed  curriculum  and  classroom  learning  and  teaching 
methodologies will require the additional learning resources that only a good school library can 
provide. The introduction of computers and other learning hardware will in turn highlight the 
urgent need for educational software currently lacking in the Uzbek language.  
 
11.  Teacher Quality and Development. Teacher quality is a key determinant of educational 
quality. Unlike in some transition economies, teachers in Uzbekistan have enjoyed regular pay 
(increases) and a range of services subsidized by the Government. Teacher education, both 
preservice and in-service, is also being reformed in content and organization. However, teacher 
quality remains a serious problem. About 50% of teachers at the primary level are considered to 
be underqualified (without higher education), and many are overspecialized in narrow subject 
areas.  Virtually  all  teachers  will  need  to  be  retrained  to  meet  new  learning  and  teaching 
requirements  as  changes  in  education  content;  methodology,  and  approach  are  being 
introduced. While these improvements are urgently needed, poor salaries relative to other 
professions in a transitional labor market and lack of clear career development opportunities 
offer  little  incentive  or  motivation  for  teachers  to  improve  (e.g.,  in-service  training  facilities 
operate at only 60% capacity, reflecting a lack of interest in participating in training). Many 
younger teachers have already abandoned teaching as a career, and, as a result, ageing is 
threatening  the  sustainability  of  the  subsector.  The  Government  has  recently  announced 
significant increases in teachers’ salaries and introduced a performance-based bonus system, 
and strengthened qualification requirements for teachers, and made in-service training a priority, 
including introducing new delivery modes such as distance education. However, insufficient 
duration  of  training,  inadequate  qualification  of  training  instructors,  lack  of  educational 
equipment and instructional resources, and other teacher support systems are critical issues to 
be addressed if the quality and relevance of in-service teacher training us to be substantially 
improved.  
 
12.  Physical Infrastructure and Equipment. Like many other sectors, basic education also 
suffers from insufficient investment in infrastructure, equipment, and facilities. As a result, the 
physical infrastructure in many schools, especially, in poorer regions, suffers from dilapidated 
buildings and classrooms and run-down lavatories; and poor water supply, electricity, heating, 
laboratories, and school libraries. A recent nationwide survey revealed that 40% of schools are 
housed  in  inappropriate  and  unfit  buildings.  Similarly,  lack  of  funding  has  led  to  lack  of 
maintenance of all school facilities and equipment, and a serious underfunding of consumable 
supplies in support of physics and chemistry labs. This is a serious constraint on practical and 
experimental work, affecting effective learning and teaching. The short supply of necessary 
office equipment such as computers and photocopiers impedes the effectiveness of school 
management. Recently the Government launched a major multiyear initiative to refocus on 
improving basic education; the principle component is improving the technical and material 
basis of schools.  
  
13.  Progress toward the Millennium Development Goals. Two Millennium Development 
Goals contain an education focus. Goal 2: Achieving universal primary education means that all 
children should be able to complete a full course of primary education. Goal 3: Promote gender 
equality  and  empower  women  requires  the  elimination  of  gender  disparity  in  primary  and 
secondary education by 2005 and from all levels of education no later than 2015.

15.  Government Strategy and Policy Framework. Since independence, the Government 
has given education high priority for the overall reform agenda. This is reflected in the close 
attention  paid  to  the  sector  by  senior  Government  officials  and  consistently  high  budget 
allocations to the sector. The strategic objective is to transform the education system to be more 
responsive  to  the  requirements  of  a  market  economy  and  democratic  society  in  the  21st 
century. Earnest reform in education began in 1997 with the adoption of a new education law

been issued to guide the implementation of the national program4. The emphasis was put on 
strengthening senior secondary and vocational education during the early years of program

sector, and budget spending on education has remained high ranging between 7–8% of gross 
domestic product or over 20% of the annual budget, reaching about 10% of gross domestic 
product or about 38% of the annual budget in 2003/04.  
 
16.  During  the  initial  years  of  implementation,  new  state  education  standards  were 
developed.  Many  reform  measures  have  been  undertaken  to  address  the  key  challenges 
discussed here. Significant progress has been made in basic education, including (i) markedly 
improving efficiency and cost-effectiveness of textbook provision; (ii) continuing progress in

children from low income families.

EXPERIENCE OF THE TEXTBOOK RENTAL SCHEME IN UZBEKISTAN 
 
A.  The Pilot Textbook Rental Scheme 
1.  Until 1998 all school textbooks were supplied free of charge to students on the basis of 
annual  loans  from  the  school  textbook  library.  The  Government  funded  all  textbooks.  As 
financial  constraints  became  more  intense  the  Government  abandoned  this  policy  and 
introduced parental purchase of textbooks. While many parents found textbooks at full price 
unaffordable, suppliers also struggled with uncertainty of demand and lack of credit. By 2000 a 
serious textbook shortage existed in many schools and the (MOPE) requested a research study 
into  alternative  approaches  to  textbook  provision  under  the  Basic  Education  Textbook 
Development Project. The research study made the following recommendations, which were 
accepted and implemented by MOPE as the pilot Textbook Rental Scheme (TRS): 
 
(i)  Design a TRS to suit the specific requirements of Uzbekistan and pilot test it to 
determine its efficacy and acceptability in Uzbekistan. 
(ii)  Maintain parental rental fee contributions within school bank accounts to create a 
school-based rental scheme. 
(iii)  Develop an evaluation scheme acceptable to the Government, MOPE, and the 
Asian Development Bank as the basis for  ‘‘go/no go” decisions on extending the 
pilot to national coverage 
 
2.  The  pilot  TRS  was  planned  in  February  2001  and  launched  in  April  2001  prior  to 
supplying  rental  scheme  books  to  schools  in  September  2001.  It  supplied  1.583  million 
textbooks in the Uzbek language (plus accompanying teacher guides) of 39 different titles 
covering 6 grade levels to over 220,000 students (4% of total enrolment) in 14 raions—one 
raion from each oblast in Uzbekistan, including the poorest raions. 
 
3.  Between September 2001, when the pilot TRS was launched, and May 2002 when the 
rental fee collection period closed, the pilot TRS collected over SUM319 million from parents 
into  the  Textbook  Revolving  Fund  account  maintained  in  the  Pakhta  Bank.  This  sum 
represented a collection rate of 93% of the target figure. This clearly demonstrated the success 
of the pilot TRS and the evaluation study concluded as follows: 
 
(i)  Parents strongly supported the TRS concept and were prepared to meet the 
annual cost of the rental fee, including those from the poorest schools.  
(ii)  Parents were motivated to pay the rental fees because they were much cheaper 
than  the  costs  of  textbook  purchase  and  because  the  fees  collected  and 
accumulated in school accounts were perceived to be of direct benefit to their 
own local community schools 
(iii)  The poorest students required ongoing financial support for the textbook rental 
fees. The study suggested that government funding for 10–15% of the poorest 
students should be sufficient to ensure full and sustainable textbook supply. 
(iv)  Four years of government/funding agency investment in start-up textbook rental 
stock was needed. Thereafter, school textbook provision could cease to be a 
charge on government budgets (except for continued Government support for the 
very  poorest  families  (iii)  and  could  be  maintained  by  parental  contributions 
alone.  
(v)  Devolved expenditure on textbooks to the level of individual schools supported 
general educational objectives in Uzbekistan on moves toward decentralization 
via school-based, per capita funding and school-based management.

(vi)  Full textbook provision for every student in every core subject at every grade 
level supported by parental contributions was realistic and achievable as long as 
rental fees were held at affordable levels. 
 
4.  As a result of the success of the pilot TRS, the Cabinet of Ministers approved the 
extension of the TRS concept to the national level from September 2002. 
 
B.  Extension of the Textbook Rental Scheme (TRS) to National Coverage 
5.  The first national phase of the TRS was launched in September 2002. It comprised 10 
titles for grade 9, all of which had been selected from competitive submissions generated by an

Uzbekistan. Textbooks were supplied in both Uzbek and Karakalpak. The second cycle for 
school  year  2003/04  supplied  textbooks  for  grades  4  and  5  in  three  languages—Uzbek,

6.  To achieve sustainability, the TRS should operate on collection rates of around 90% of

(i)  In 2002/03 only 72% of the schools were initially supplied with TRS textbooks as 
a result of a shortfall in Government funding. This caused confusion among many

(ii)  In 2003/04 many of the textbooks were not supplied to schools until January

expected to be paid into the bank accounts in the next 2 months. 
(iii)  The  Basic  Education  Textbook  Development  Project  is  currently  nearing

and schools is difficult. 
(iv)  A recent school mapping exercise suggests that enrollment numbers may have

ESTABLISHMENT OF THE REPUBLICAN TEXTBOOK REVOLVING FUND FOUNDATION  
 
1.  The textbook rental scheme (TRS) was piloted successfully in 2001 under the Basic 
Education Textbook Development Project to address the provision of affordable textbooks after 
the Government decided to stop supplying free textbooks starting in 1998. Under the TRS 
parents rent textbooks at a fee only a fraction of the full purchase price; textbooks are designed 
to last 4 years. Starting from 2002, the TRS is being gradually extended nationwide until 2007 
when all grades (2–9) in all schools will be covered by the TRS. The extension of TRS coverage 
to grades 6, 7, and 8 will be supported by the Project during 2005–2007. The rental fees 
collected are kept in a Ministry of Public Education (MOPE) account with each school having a 
subaccount identifying its portion of the fees collected. As of 1 July 2004, a total of SUM4.7 
billion (or 47% of the total costs of TRS introduced during 2001–2003) had been accumulated. 
This amount is expected to increase steadily until the first cycle of textbook replacement (for 
grade 9) begins in 2006 when there will be a drawdown on the collected amount. At full national 
coverage the average balance of the rental fees collected is projected to be about $30 million, 
and no further budgetary support will be required except for the continued support, which the 
Government has committed to, for the socially unprotected. This amounts to about 15% of total 
enrolment who cannot afford to pay even the rental fees. The main sources of TRS financing 
are the Government (budget and Asian Development Bank (ADB) loans) and parents who pay 
rental fees. While the Government provides the startup capital, once replacement of textbooks 
begins, starting in 2006, no further budgetary support will be needed except for the socially 
unprotected.  
 
2.  Based on the experience in Uzbekistan since 2001 and lessons learned elsewhere, a 
number  of  key  principles  have  been  identified  for  TRS  sustainability  and  the  provision  of 
affordable textbooks to all students nationwide. First, rental fee collection rates have to be 
sufficiently high (80% or more), which requires widespread support of parents. A key to win and 
maintain parental support is the guarantee that the rental fees will be used for the purpose for 
which they are intended, the sustainable supply of low-cost textbooks. Second, high collection 
rates depend critically on overall supervision and management. Experience elsewhere (e.g., 
Armenia, Tajikistan) has highlighted the importance of systematic supervision and monitoring. 
Third, continued government support will be required for supporting those students (about 15% 
based on Uzbekistan experience) who are too poor to pay even rental fees—to ensure equity 
and social protection. Fourth, affordable rental fees require long book life to allow for maximum 
cost  amortization,  which  in  turn  is  based  on  high  physical  production  specifications.  The 
collected rental fees will have to be maintained intact and without misappropriation or diversion 
into other uses. In education systems where financial resources are scarce there will always be 
pressure to divert accumulated rental fees to other urgent needs unless they are specifically 
protected. Diversion of funding undermines the TRS’ capacity to purchase replacement copies 
in the required quantities, which in turn undermines the entire TRS concept. Finally, centralized 
versus school-based management of TRS fees will have distinct advantages in terms of the 
capacity  to  maintain  the  fund  value  through  financial  and  risk  management,  and  internal 
systematic monitoring and control.  
 
3.  The Government, assisted by ADB, has been considering various options based on 
these principles in order to institutionalize the sustainable provision of textbooks. Consultations 
have been held with all stakeholders over the past 2 years, including seminars, workshops, 
interviews, field visits, and a nationwide public campaign on the TRS. ADB missions have 
worked closely with the Government and local legal experts on the issue since 2004. As a 
result, agreement has been reached on the establishment of a republican textbook revolving 
fund foundation (RTRFF) as an independent legal entity. Its main objective is to manage the

rental fees accumulated under the TRS and textbook procurement and distribution on orders 
placed by schools and parents. In achieving its main objective, the RTRFF will be required to 
fulfill the following: 
 
(i)  Consolidate parent and school support for the TRS and represent their interests. 
(ii)  Ensure that the textbook funds are operated within the Government’s education 
policy guidelines. 
(iii)  Guarantee the security and proper use of the rental fees collected from parents. 
(iv)  Ensure the most effective use of scarce resources and minimize the costs of 
textbook production.

(vi)  Coordinate textbook development policies and practices with MOPE. 
(vii)  Provide  independent  monitoring,  data  collection  and  accurate  order

(viii)  Organize efficient and on-time procurement and delivery of textbooks to schools 
according to school orders. 
 
4.  The RTRFF will be governed by  a board of trustees comprising representatives of 
schools, parents, the Mahalla (local community), as well as the government. The board will 
appoint RTRFF management. As a foundation, its charter will specify in more detail its scope of 
activities,  responsibilities,  and  obligations  in  accordance  with  Uzbek  law.  However, 
transparency, accountability, and financial prudence are its principles of operation. A small 
percentage of the interest on the accumulated rental fees can be made available to pay the 
operating costs of the RTRFF; to maintain a permanent, specialist staff to manage the rental 
fees on behalf of parents and schools; and to ensure sustainability of textbook provision. A 
maximum limit on the use of funds for administration purposes can be established as part of the

with the Ministry of Justice with consultation and agreement by ADB prior to its registration; and

Although  Uzbekistan  has  achieved  virtual  universal  primary  completion  and  gender  equity  in  basic 
education,  the  Project  will  contribute  to  the  achievement  of  Millennium  Development  Goal  targets, 
particularly in improving all aspects of the quality of basic education and ensuring that children belonging 
to ethnic minorities have access to compulsory basic education of good quality. The Project contributes to 
the accumulation of human capital, which is essential for higher incomes and sustained economic growth. 
It helps reduce poverty by increasing the productivity of the poor and by equipping people with the skills 
they need to participate fully in the economy and in society.  
 
Within the context of basic education reforms, the Project will enhance the curriculum by making it more 
relevant to the needs of the labor market, will improve access by making textbooks more affordable for the 
poorest parents, and will broaden community participation by decentralizing education management and 
financing. Improving the quality and relevance of the basic education system will be key priorities for 
reducing poverty and preventing the intergenerational transmission of poverty.   
 
The survey report indicated that the Project will benefit 6 million students in grades 2 to 9 in which 27% are 
students from poor families. Four hundred thousand students from minority language schools will receive 
new and better quality textbooks and supplementary reading materials. Secondary beneficiaries include 
160,000 teachers and about 1,200 school librarians who will receive new teacher guides and in-service 
training. In addition, 40 curriculum developers and assessment specialists, 270 textbook evaluators, and a 
new generation of textbook authors and publishers plus the Uzbek printing industry will benefit from 
training in modern techniques in their respective professional areas. The provision of basic information and 
communication technology (ICT) capacity in 1,000 school libraries will support an increase in the volume 
and quality of information exchange, and will develop policies for future ICT investments in the sector. 
 
The Government will continue to earmark budget support for subsidizing textbook rental fees for about 
15% of the students that began in 2002/03. Provision of computers and supplementary books and 
materials for use in upgraded school libraries will improve the learning environment in schools, which will 
lead to higher achievements of pupils. About 40% of the investment in upgraded school libraries will be 
targeted to the poorest schools in the country.
